stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 11, focusing on implementing and debugging an elevator mechanic for Bowser's office. He also reviewed new Wiggler animations from Zeina and programmed the dynamic dialogue system for the Wiggler-led mission. The stream also included discussions on AI's impact on creativity, future level concepts, and his YouTube content strategy.

development_findings.summary: The game is estimated to be 75% complete.
A future level, 'Wild West Valley,' is in the concept phase. It will feature a cowboy theme, wanted posters, and missions centered on capturing villains, with a Drybones sheriff suggested as a boss.
development_findings.quote: The Wild West Valley. There's gonna be cowboys, you're gonna be catching like villains that are running around. There's gonna be wanted posters. It's gonna be so scenic.

development_findings.summary: A mission was designed where players can enter Bowser's office at different points in the game. The narrative culminates in Bowser sending a 'strike breaker' to deal with his striking minions, triggering a boss fight.
development_findings.quote: So, you can enter Bowser's office anytime you want... And when you enter it in the third one, then Bowser's gonna talk about how he's gonna send him a strike breaker.

development_findings.summary: Kaze articulated a design principle of avoiding tight spaces to prevent camera issues, citing the example of widening the elevator shaft for a better player experience.
development_findings.quote: I had to extend it a lot so that it doesn't suck while kicking up here... Honestly the solution is to just not make tight spaces.

development_findings.summary: An options menu has been implemented, featuring settings for interlacing and FPS limits that can improve performance by up to 25%.
A bug causing certain enemies to fall through the floor was fixed. The issue was traced to gravity continuously reducing their Y-velocity until it was low enough to clip through collision.
The intro cutscene's environment was redesigned from a simple cardboard box to a full child's bedroom to be more visually interesting and immersive.
The game will feature five collectible Yoshi Coins in each level, which will replace the traditional 100-coin stars.
development_findings.quote: You can find five Yoshi coins per level in this game and they replace the one on Coin Stars.

context_findings.summary: Kaze strategically plans game releases for September, believing it to be a safer period to avoid takedowns from Nintendo.
context_findings.quote: I think I like to release my games around September... because that's the time where it's like least likely Nintendo's gonna take them down.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed philosophical concerns that AI devalues human skill and purpose, predicting that large corporations will monopolize the technology by training it on proprietary data.
context_findings.quote: The question is the skills that AI lets you skip learning are those even valuable anymore if AI can do them for you? I think AI is a bit different because now AI is starting to do the things that we humans thought we were uniquely good at and it's like adding so much futility to human existence.

context_findings.summary: To mitigate legal risks from Nintendo, Kaze plans to sell merchandise like a custom box and manual for the game, but not the physical game cartridge itself.
context_findings.quote: I'm not gonna make a physical cartridge because if I do I will get sued to shit. But I might make a box and an instruction booklet and all that and I'm probably gonna sell those as merch.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed that he and Zeina are attempting to buy a house but his income is considered too low to secure a loan, highlighting the financial challenges of his profession despite being able to afford the mortgage payments.
context_findings.quote: I actually can't get a loan right now because my income is too low. But we can afford the house. We just can't get the loan.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discussed his YouTube strategy, noting that he pays an editor for Shorts but finds them unprofitable on average and struggles with the channel's overall profitability.
context_findings.quote: YouTube is just not profitable for me because my channel is not that big or interesting.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested evolving the game's intro cutscene from a simple cardboard box to a fully modeled child's bedroom to create a more immersive atmosphere.
biobak.quote: Should we have a full on child's room model around it? Yeah, honestly I would like that.

biobak.summary: Biobak proposed including a scannable QR code inside the planned physical merchandise box that would link to the game's download.
Provided feedback on a level's reworked cloud visuals, stating the new version looks 'so much more vast' and less 'caged in'.

badub.summary: Badub composed a new song for the second Bowser level that features dynamic audio channels, allowing for different indoor and outdoor versions of the track.

zeina.summary: Zeina created and delivered a set of new animations for the Wiggler character, including walking, jumping, and various angry poses, which Kaze then implemented.
zeina.quote: I'm just finishing the jump for Wiggler and I'm gonna send him over once he's done.

zeina.summary: Zeina revealed she is a fan of the Koopalings, sparking a playful debate with Kaze over their quality as Mario Kart characters.

key_stories.title: The Elevator to Bowser's Office
key_stories.summary: Kaze designed and implemented an elevator mechanic for Bowser's office. The development involved coding the core functionality and then engaging in a significant debugging effort to fix issues with its state logic and player interaction, ultimately resulting in a polished feature.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to build a functional elevator to transport the player to Bowser's office as part of a key mission.
key_stories.process: Kaze coded the elevator's vertical movement, the logic for the doors to open and close, and associated sound effects. He then systematically debugged issues related to proximity detection, movement triggers, and state management to ensure the feature was reliable.
key_stories.outcome: After multiple rounds of coding and debugging, Kaze created a working elevator with proper door logic that responds correctly to the player's position and the elevator's state.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, why the fuck is it not moving? What is wrong?

key_stories.title: Wiggler's Supervisory Role
key_stories.summary: Kaze designed a mission featuring Wiggler as a disgruntled supervisor. He created a dynamic dialogue system where Wiggler's complaints act as clues for the player. As each objective is met, the related dialogue disappears, providing a clear sense of progression.
key_stories.challenge: The first star of the level required a mission where the player gets hints from a supervisor character (Wiggler) about how to disrupt a construction site.
key_stories.process: Kaze, with input from chat, brainstormed dialogue for Wiggler complaining about his workers. He then programmed a system where each of Wiggler's complaints corresponds to a task. Completing a task makes that dialogue unavailable, narrowing down the hints for the player.
key_stories.outcome: A dynamic dialogue system was implemented for Wiggler. His dialogue provides hints, and as the player completes objectives, the corresponding dialogue is removed, effectively guiding them through the mission until Wiggler has nothing left to say.
key_stories.key_quote: He has all these dialogues from the beginning, but whenever you destroy something, the dialogue is no longer available. So it gives you a hint as to what to do next.

key_stories.title: The AI Existential Crisis
key_stories.summary: During a discussion on AI, Kaze expressed deep philosophical concerns about its potential to devalue human skill and create a sense of futility. He also predicted a future where corporations regulate and monopolize AI, using it to widen the gap with independent creators.
key_stories.challenge: A discussion about using AI in development evolved into a deeper philosophical debate about its impact on human value and creativity.
key_stories.process: Kaze argued that AI devalues the process of learning and skill acquisition, which he sees as fundamental to human purpose. He predicted that corporations would push for regulations that allow them to use AI trained on proprietary data, creating a significant competitive advantage.
key_stories.outcome: The conversation revealed Kaze's core philosophy regarding technology and human purpose. He articulated a strong concern that AI could lead to existential futility and would likely be monopolized by large corporations, stifling independent creators.
key_stories.key_quote: It's like why even try if something better can be done without any effort?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly asked Biobak, 'Did you ever finish the conspiracy theory Yoshi room?' No further details about this room were discussed.
questions: What is the concept behind the 'conspiracy theory Yoshi room'?
What role was it intended to play in the game, and what is its current status?
Biobak, what was your design inspiration for this concept?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated he will sell a box and manual as merchandise but not a cartridge to avoid legal issues. Biobak suggested adding a QR code inside the box linking to the game download.
questions: Can you elaborate on the full strategy for the physical merchandise release?
How do you navigate the constant legal risks from Nintendo while still engaging with your community in this way?
What are the long-term plans for ensuring the QR code link remains active and accessible?

open_questions.topic: Financial Realities of an Independent Creator
open_questions.context: Kaze candidly shared that his income is too low to qualify for a home loan, despite working a full-time job in the game industry and running a YouTube channel.
questions: How do you manage the financial pressures of a day job while dedicating immense time to a passion project like this?
In what ways does your financial reality influence the project's scope, timeline, and creative decisions?
Beyond finishing the game, what does 'success' look like for you with this project and your work in general?

open_questions.context: Kaze reviewed Wiggler animations created by Zeina, imported them into the game, and commented on the process.
questions: Can you describe the collaborative workflow between you for creative assets like animations?
What specific tools do you use for animation, modeling, and integrating assets into the game engine?
How do you handle feedback and revisions on artistic work to ensure it aligns with the technical requirements and overall vision?

open_questions.context: Kaze described a future 'Wild West Valley' level concept, including cowboys, wanted posters, and a potential Drybones sheriff boss.
questions: What are the core gameplay mechanics you envision for the Wild West level?
What inspired this theme, and how do you plan to make it feel unique within the Mario universe?
Can you discuss the types of villains and boss fights you are considering for this level?
